title-group.article-title: Comparison of Cochlear Implant Performance after Round Window Electrode Insertion Compared with Traditional Cochleostomy

article-meta.aff: 1New York Medical College, Valhalla, New York, USA
2New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, New York, New York, USA

author-notes.corresp: Ana H. Kim, MD, New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, 310 East 14th St, Department of Otolaryngology, 6th Floor, New York, NY 10003, USA Email: hkim@nyee.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © American Academy of Otolaryngology—Head and Neck Surgery Foundation 2013
permissions.copyright-holder: Official journal of the American Academy of Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery Foundation

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: To compare speech perception after undergoing round window (RW) electrode insertion with those who underwent traditional cochleostomy (C) cochlear implant (CI) surgery.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: Case series with chart review.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: Academic cochlear implant center.

sec.title: Subjects
sec.p: Patients who met CI criteria with favorable intraoperative RW anatomy who underwent RW CI electrode insertion. Patients who underwent traditional C surgery were matched for age, duration of deafness, and preoperative hearing.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Postoperative speech performance using the consonant-nucleus-consonant (CNC) test, Northwestern University Children’s Perception of Speech (NUCHIPS), and Hearing in Noise Test (HINT) between 3 and 48 months after CI.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 84 patients underwent RW insertion between 2004 and 2011. Of these, 55 had pre- and postoperative speech perception data for analysis. Average age of implantation ranged from 2.4 to 87.3 years (mean ± SD, 42.1 ± 24.2 years) for RW patients. Average age of implantation for matched traditional C patients ranged from 2.3 to 85.6 years (mean ± SD, 43.3 ± 25.0 years). No significant differences in postoperative CI speech perception scores were noted between the RW and C groups at 12 months post-CI (RW group, 55.28% ± 23.26% vs C group, 53.19% ± 24.14%; P = .70).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Our study found that patients with favorable RW anatomy who underwent RW CI electrode insertion demonstrated comparable speech perception compared with the traditional cochleostomy insertion group.

body.p: Cochlear implants (CIs) have given select populations of hearing-impaired individuals the ability to experience the sensation of sound. More than 200,000 adults and children worldwide have been implanted,1 and advances in surgical technique and technology have provided benefits to speech development and sound appreciation. Strides made toward improving CI auditory outcome in a wider range of potential recipients have encouraged the conservation of residual hearing capabilities through atraumatic cochlear implant electrode insertion, thereby ensuring preservation of the cochlear architecture as much as possible.

Several studies have shown that this combined hearing, known as combined electric and acoustic stimulation (EAS) when originally developed in 1999, demonstrates improved overall hearing, music awareness, and speech recognition.2-5 Success of EAS is dependent on preserving and minimizing damage to structures within the inner ear that are vital for auditory function such as the hair cells, as well as maintaining the discrete cochlear compartments (scala media, scala tympani, and scala vestibuli). Even in cases of conventional length CI candidates, post-CI speech perception improvements were demonstrated by minimizing insertional trauma,6 further providing the impetus toward using minimally invasive techniques in all CI recipients and conservation of residual hearing.

Successful hearing preservation has been reported using the round window (RW) electrode insertion.7,8 The RW membrane serves as a consistent landmark during CI surgery. Its continuity with the scala tympani ensures electrode insertion into this compartment while theoretically circumventing damage to the basilar membrane.9 Three-dimensional analyses of the RW and surrounding structures have advocated inserting at the anterior-inferior quadrant of the RW membrane to avoid the electrode from violating the basilar membrane that may result in its placement in the scala vestibuli.10,11 Other benefits of RW insertion include minimizing acoustic trauma from drilling on the otic bone when creating a “traditional” cochleostomy that can exceed 130 dB12,13 and reducing the iatrogenic damage and reactive inflammation that results from the use of a micro-drill when creating the cochleostomy.14,15 Lastly, postoperative vertigo and loss of vestibular function may also be minimized with the RW approach over the traditional cochleostomy approach.16

Despite these proven benefits of RW electrode insertion, some still believe that the traditional method of creating a cochleostomy just anterior/inferior to the RW remains superior in terms of CI speech outcome. The purpose of this study was to compare speech perception after cochlear implantation using the RW membrane as a portal for electrode insertion in lieu of the traditional cochleostomy (C) technique.

sec.title: Patient Selection
sec.p: Institutional review board approval was obtained for the study (protocol 08.17-NYEEI). Participants were drawn from patients undergoing CI between 2004 and 2011. Patients meeting the following criteria were included: CI candidates with favorable anatomy intraoperatively showing complete visualization of the RW membrane through the facial recess and with postoperative speech perception scores using the same test at various time points. A group of CI patients who underwent cochlear implantation via the traditional cochleostomy electrode insertion due to unfavorable RW visualization were matched for age of implantation, duration of deafness, and preoperative hearing to serve as the comparison group.

sec.title: Round Window Cochleostomy Technique
sec.p: The RW is identified through the facial recess. Any fibrous and mucosal adhesions that may be present obscuring the RW membrane are carefully removed using a fine pick. In some cases, the bony overhang obscuring full visualization of the RW membrane is drilled away using a 1.5-mm diamond burr (Figure 1). Once the RW membrane is completely in view, a small opening is made in the anteroinferior corner using a fine pick. A 0.3-mm footplate rasp may be used to slightly enlarge this opening. The tip of the electrode array is slowly inserted through this opening. After the electrode insertion, the remainder of the implantation is routine.

caption.p: Round window technique. Facial recess approach (A). Removal of bony overhang (BO) (B). Lateral semi-circular canal (LSC), oval window (OW), incus (inc), stapes (S), chorda tympani (CT), and facial nerve (FC). Printed with permission from ©Continuum Health Partners.

sec.title: Audiometric Testing and Data Analysis
sec.p: Speech perception was tested using the consonant-nucleus-consonant (CNC) test, Hearing in Noise Test (HINT), and Northwestern University Children’s Perception of Speech (NUCHIPS) based on the patient’s capacity. Test time points included approximately 3, 6, 12, 24, 36, and 48 months post-CI. Speech perception scores between the RW and C groups were analyzed via paired-samples t test. Significance was set at P < .05. Post hoc power analysis was calculated using G*Power.17 Analysis was conducted to determine the discernable effect size with a 2-tailed test at an α of 0.05 with the respective patient populations for each of the speech perception tests.

sec.title: Patient Demographics
sec.p: There were a total of 659 patients who underwent cochlear implantation between 2004 and 2011. Of these patients, 84 underwent RW electrode insertion, but only 55 had consistent speech perception data using the same speech tests throughout the postoperative follow-up period. Total number of patients tested with CNC at 0 to 6, 6 to 12, 12 to 24, and 24 to 48 months were 36, 32, 26, and 13, respectively. Total number of patients tested with HINT at 0 to 6, 6 to 12, and 12 to 36 months were 15, 11, and 7, respectively. Total number of patients tested with NUCHIPS at 0 to 6, 6 to 12, and 12 to 36 months were 9, 7, and 9, respectively. Of note, some patients were given multiple test types at the various time points. Average age at implantation ranged from 2.4 to 87.3 years (mean ± SD, 42.1 ± 24.2 years) for the RW patients. The average age of the 88 patients who underwent traditional C ranged from 2.3 to 85.6 years (mean ± SD, 43.3 ± 25.0 years). There were 8 bilateral CI patients who underwent RW electrode insertion in one ear and C insertion in the contralateral ear, thereby serving as intrasubject/interaural comparisons. Patient demographic information is further detailed in Table 1.

tr.td: Age at implantation, y, mean ± SD
Age at hearing loss, y, mean ± SD

fn.p: Abbreviations: C, cochleostomy; L, left; R, right; RW, round window.

sec.title: Speech Performance Comparison between the RW and C Groups
sec.p: Average speech perception scores at approximately 3 to 6, 6 to 12, 12 to 24, and 24 to 48 months showed no significant differences between the RW vs the C groups (Table 2). The NUCHIPS at 0 to 6 months was the only subset that demonstrated a potential level of significant difference (P < .07), with the C group demonstrating a higher score (81.25%) compared with the RW group (64.44%). Individual test scores at various time points are shown for CNC (Figure 2A), NUCHIPS (Figure 2B), and HINT (Figure 2C). Simple linear regression curves between the RW and C groups demonstrated no significant difference over time between the 2 groups.

fn.p: Abbreviations: C, cochleostomy; CI, cochlear implant; CNC, consonant-nucleus-consonant test; HINT, Hearing in Noise Test; NUCHIPS, Northwestern University Children’s Perception of Speech; RW, round window.

caption.p: Comparison of speech perception scores between round window (RW) and cochleostomy (C) groups using the consonant-nucleus-consonant (CNC) test (A), Northwestern University Children’s Perception of Speech (NUCHIPS) (B), and Hearing in Noise Test (HINT) (C).

sec.title: Intrasubject/Interaural Comparison of Speech Performance
sec.p: Eight patients in our RW series were bilateral cochlear implant recipients who previously underwent C insertion in the contralateral ear. Four were pediatric cases (aged 2, 4, 6, and 11 years at the time of RW surgery), and 4 were adults (aged 37, 38, 50, and 59 years at the time of RW surgery). Average interval between the first and second implant was 5 months. Interaural comparison shows similar speech performance in all 8 patients when their speech performance was compared at 12 months post-CI testing between the RW and control ear within subject (Figure 3).

caption.p: Interaural comparison of speech perception. Eight patients with round window (RW) insertion and cochleostomy (C) insertion show similar post–cochlear implant speech perception at approximately 12 months with no significant difference.

sec.title: Data Comparison
sec.p: A post hoc power analysis was used to interpret the significance of the statistical comparisons. The modest sample size may have precluded the discernment of smaller effect sizes, with power only reaching an effective level at 90 samples at an α of 0.05 for a 2-tailed test at an effect size of 0.3. The sample sizes of the speech perception tests CNC, HINT, and NUCHIPS (43, 20, and 18 patients, respectively) would allow for detecting a medium to large effect size above the recommended 0.8 level of statistical power. A Bonferroni adjustment was also made to compensate for the multiple comparisons being made within each speech perception test. A Bonferroni-adjusted significance level of 0.0125 for CNC and 0.0166 for the HINT and NUCHIPS tests was applied to compensate for type I errors.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The importance of hearing preservation and atraumatic CI surgical techniques are active areas of current research. The relevance of these principles is predicated on the notion that they lead to improved patient outcomes in speech awareness and perception. Currently, there is a lack of consensus on the amount of residual hearing that is worth preserving; this includes audiometric criteria that constitute hearing preservation after CI surgery and the long-term benefits of preserving residual hearing by minimizing iatrogenic damage/trauma to the cochlea. However, it is hoped that preserving as much of the cochlear architecture will allow for application of future technologies in restoring hearing.

To this end, the RW technique is an atraumatic method for electrode insertion. Our study found comparable CI speech perception between the RW and traditional cochleostomy group, suggesting that RW is an acceptable route of electrode insertion. However, proper techniques should be strictly adhered to in order to ensure proper electrode placement. The RW membrane should be completely visualized by removing any bony overhang that is present. This is essential to ensure electrode insertion at the anterior/inferior quadrant of the RW membrane, thereby avoiding the “cochlear hook” that may potentially deflect the trajectory of the electrode insertion into the scala vestibule rather than the preferred placement within the scala tympani.18 The RW membrane should be opened using a fine pick with minimal suctioning of the perilymph. These steps minimize unnecessary inflammatory response that can lead to inner ear structural damage resulting in loss of residual hearing and possibly even CI “soft failures” that have been linked to increased inflammatory processes.19

We recognize that not every case can or should be performed using the RW technique. The RW orientation visible through the facial recess is variable—it may be too posteriorly or anteriorly displaced from the surgeon’s view through the facial recess. In addition, the variable course of the facial nerve and chorda tympani may further limit the facial recess dimensions, potentially restricting access to the RW niche.20 However, with favorable anatomy, the use of the RW insertion technique appears to be a viable method of CI electrode insertion.

To our knowledge, this is the first study demonstrating the long-term results (up to 48 months) of CI speech perception after RW electrode insertion. Our data demonstrated comparable speech perception scores in patients who received RW vs the traditional cochleostomy insertion. Our study did not focus on assessing hearing preservation rates in the RW group since these patients were not EAS candidates, and thus they did not have relevant residual hearing. Perhaps the RW technique applied to patients with relevant residual hearing may result in improved speech perception outcomes compared with traditional cochlestomy. As atraumatic insertions become more widespread, an important consensus needs to be formulated in defining the preoperative audiometric criteria for residual hearing worth preserving, as well as defining what constitutes hearing preservation post-CI. In addition, our current audiometric testing paradigm may not be appropriately assessing the benefits of atraumatic electrode insertion and the potential benefits of preserving residual hearing. We currently lack subjective measures such as quality-of-life assessments unique to cochlear implant patients that may distinguish potential benefits of atraumatic CI surgery. As cochlear implant technology advances, so too must the surgical techniques and tools to assess outcome measures.
